---

Google Collab and AWS all have free credits through different partnerships that you could use as well. You should also ask your advisor for computer; they more than likely can either give you access to machines or give you credits to run for free online (at the aforementioned places).

Hi everyone. I recently started doing some research through URAP and am currently working with ~17,000 images to train a CNN classifier for them. The problem is that at the moment I am training the classifier using my personal laptop (an XPS 15) and hence even with such a (relatively small) dataset, it takes quite a while for it to train. Hence, whenever I try changing the hyperparameters to see which ones best suit my data, I have to wait a really long time before I can get the results, which is slowing down my research quite a bit. Moreover, to be able to train the CNN for a sufficient number of epochs that results in substantial accuracy (around ~100 epochs for my needs), I have to keep my laptop running the entire day and night. I'm worried that having my GPU constantly working for such a large period of time will lead to the device getting damaged and that would be disastrous.

Hence, I was wondering if Berkeley had any freely available resources (such as servers we could ssh into) that were built for such tasks (CUDA enabled GPUs, etc.)? That way, I could simply train my CNN using those resources which should greatly speed up my tasks and even allow me to rest my own laptop's GPU.

Lastly, for people who are working in such fields, what would you recommend as the best paid (cheap/efficient/etc) option that we could use to train CNNs with? In the case that the university doesn't have any free resources, I am thinking of requesting my professor to allocate some funds that we could use to rent servers on which we could train our model. 

I'm really sorry if this is kind of a trivial question for those in the field, or if I'm missing something really obvious. It's just that this is my first time doing research at the university, especially in the ML field, and I'm really not sure what resources I have available to use.
history.subject: Berkeley Resources for Training CNN
